As mentioned, the present invention also envisions solid state pulverizing of one or more virgin polymeric materials as feedstock.
If two or more thermo-dynamically incompatible virgin polymers are present in the virgin material feedstock, in-situ compatibilization of the virgin polymers should be achievable.

For purposes of illustration and not limitation, virgin LDPE pellets were solid state pulverized using the aforementioned Berstorff ZE-40A twin screw extruder with heating (barrel zones 2-4 heated) and without heating (all barrel zones cooled) pursuant to the invention.

The virgin LDPE pellets were solid state pulverized with heating (barrel zones 2-4 heated) using processing parameters similar to those set forth in TABLE I for "w/heat" solid state pulverization of the solely scrap flake LDPE feedstock.
The virgin LDPE pellets were also solid state pulverized without heating (all barrel zones cooled) using processing parameters similar to those set forth in TABLE I for "No heat" solid state pulverization of scrap LDPE feedstock.

The solid state pulverized virgin LDPE particulates (powder) were injection molded in the manner described hereabove for the pulverized scrap particulates.
The virgin LDPE pellets were similarly injection molded.

The physical properties of the injection molded specimens are shown in TABLE V below.
It can be seen that the physical properties of injection molded pulverized specimens are generally comparable to those of injection molded pellet specimens.

Virgin PC pellets also were solid state pulverized with heating (barrel zones 2-4 heated) using the Berstorff ZE-40A twin screw extruder.
The virgin PC pellets were solid state pulverized using processing parameters similar to those set forth in TABLE I for "W/heat" solid state pulverization of scrap PP thickness (slightly higher temperature).

The pulverized particulates and virgin pellets were injection molded as described hereabove.
Thy physical properties of the injection molded specimens are shown in TABLE V. It can be seen that injection molded pulverized powder PC specimens and injection molded pellet specimens exhibited comparable physical properties.

Regardless of the composition of the polymeric feedstock supplied to the extruder, the present invention is advantageous in that energy consumption of the solid state pulverization process is lower than that of conventional batch grinding processes.
In addition, the present invention provides a continuous, once-through solid state pulverization process in contrast to conventional batch grinding techniques.
While the invention has been described in terms of specific embodiments thereof, it is not intended to be limited thereto but rather only to the extent set forth hereafter in the following claims.

claim.claim-text: What is claimed is:
A method of preparing polymer particles comprising the steps of:

(a) providing a supply of polymer material, (b) effecting a chemical change to the polymer material by application of mechanical energy to convert the material into a powder solely in the solid state in the presence of cooling sufficient to maintain the material in the solid state during said conversion into said powder;
and (c) discharging the resulting particles of powder.
2. A product by the process of claim 1.
3. The process of claim 1 wherein the polymer material is converted into powder having a maximum dimension of less than about 500 microns.
4. The process of claim 1 wherein the step of effecting a chemical change and converting the polymer material is effected by co-rotating, mechanical screws.
5. The process of claim 1 wherein the supply of polymer material comprises a mixture of chemically different polymers.

6. A method of preparing polymer particles of substantially uniform chemical characteristics from a mixture of different polymer materials, comprising the steps of: (a) providing a supply mixture of different polymer materials; (b) effecting a chemical change to the mixture of polymer materials by converting the mixture into a powder by application of mechanical energy while maintaining the mixture solely in the solid state;
and (c) collecting the powder.

7. A method for manufacture of a powder of polymer material from a supply of polymeric material in the form of chips or particles, comprising, in combination, the following steps: (a) compounding a polymer material of polymeric chips or particles; (b) introducing the polymer material into a mechanical device of the type having an inlet for the polymer material, means for converting material into a powder and thereby effecting chemical change to the polymer material in the presence of cooling sufficient to maintain the polymer material solely in the solid state during the conversion to said powder, an outlet for the material, and means for cooling the temperature of the polymer material between the inlet and outlet; (c) cooling the polymer material to maintain the polymer material in the solid state without melting within the mechanical device; (d) converting the solid state polymer material within the mechanical device to chemically alter the polymer material and form said powder;
and (e) discharging the powder from the outlet.
8. A product by the process of claim 7.
9. The process of claim 7 wherein the polymer material comprises a mixture of polymers.
10. The process of claim 7 wherein the mechanical device effects chemical change by sold state shear of the polymer material.
11. The process of claim 7 including the step of converting the polymer material to form particles of powder which have less than 500 microns maximum dimension.
12. The process of claim 1, claim 6 or claim 7 wherein the chemical change includes bond rupture of the chemical bonds of polymer material.

13. The method of claim 1, claim 6 or claim 7 wherein the polymer material is a quantity of polymeric chips, said chips having a size in the range of about 0.10 to 0.30 inches maximum width dimension and about 0.01 to 0.06 thickness dimension.

14. The method of claim 1, claim 6 or claim 7 wherein the polymer material comprises a mixture of two or more polymeric materials from the group consisting of HDPE, LDPE, LLDPE, PP, PS, PET, PVC, polycarbonate (PC), acrylonitrile butadiene styrene (ABS) and polyphenylene oxide (PPO).
15. The method of claim 1, claim 6 or claim 7 including the further step of supplying an inert gas blanket to cool the discharged powder and prevent oxidation of the particles of powder.
16. The method of claim 1, claim 6 or claim 7 wherein the morphology of the discharged powder is altered.
17. The method of claim 1, claim 6 or claim 7 including the further step of subsequently processing the powder directly without pelletization.
18. The method of claim 1, claim 6 or claim 7 including the further step of applying the powder as a coating material.
19. The method of claim 1, claim 6 or claim 7 including the preliminary step of dry blending a mixture of chemically distinct polymer materials.

20. The method of claim 17 wherein the subsequent processing step is taken from the group consisting of rotational molding, blow molding, extrusion, molding, spray coating powder coating and thermal spray coating.
21. The method of claim 1, claim 6 or claim 7 including the preliminary step of comminution of the polymer materials prior to forming a powder.
22. The method of claim 7 including formation of the powder in a single pass through the mechanical device.
23. The method of claim 1, claim 6 or claim 7 wherein the polymer material is comprised of at least two distinct polymers having different glass transition temperatures.
24. The method of claim 1, claim 6 or claim 7 wherein the powder formed has a greater free radical density than the starting polymer materials.

25. A method of preparing polymer particles to be used for coatings and in polymer processes, comprising the steps of: (a) providing a supply of a mixture of chemically distinct polymer materials in the solid state; (b) effecting a chemical change to the mixture by application of mechanical energy to the materials in the presence of cooling sufficient to maintain the materials in the mixture in the solid state during said change and thereby compatibilizing the mixture to form homogeneous particles upon effecting said chemical change;
and (c) discharging the resulting compatibilized particles.

26. A method of modifying polymeric materials, comprising the steps of: (a) providing a supply of polymeric material; (b) modifying the polymeric material by application of mechanical energy thereto through solid state shear pulverization in the presence of cooling sufficient to maintain the material in the solid state during pulverization to effect a chemical change in the material;
and (c) discharging the resulting modified material.

27. The method of claim 1, including the step of: providing as the material to be modified a material selected from the group consisting of virgin polymeric materials, post-consumer polymeric waste materials, amorphous polymeric scrap materials, crystalline polymeric scrap materials, blended polymeric materials, thermodynamically incompatible polymeric blends, multi-colored polymeric blends, industrial polymeric waste materials, and mixtures thereof.

28. The method of claim 26, including the step of: providing as the material to be blended polymeric scrap materials selected from the group consisting of HDPE, LDPE, LLDPE, PP, PS, PET, PVC, PC, ABS/PC, PPO, and mixtures thereof.

29. The method of claim 26, including the step of: providing as the material to be modified a material selected from the group consisting of thermoplastics, polymer alloys, thermosets, elastomers, polymer blends and mixtures thereof.
30. The method of claim 28, including the step of: selecting as the material a mixture of HDPE, LDPE and PP.
31. The method of claim 28, including the step of: selecting as the material a mixture of HDPE and PP.
32. The method of claim 28, including the step of: selecting as the material a mixture of HDPE and LDPE.
33. The method of claim 26, including the step of: providing the material to be modified in the form of flakes or pellets.
34. The method of claim 33, including the step of: providing flakes having a size of from about 0.10 to about 0.30 inches in width and from about 0.02 to about 0.06 inches in thickness.
35. The method of claim 34, including the step of: forming the flakes by a process selected from the group consisting of grinding, chopping. and shredding.
36. The method of claim 26, including the step of: detecting enhanced reactivity by the presence of free radicals.
37. The method of claim 28, including the step of: maintaining the material at a temperature below the melting temperature of the individual components.
38. The method of claim 26, including the step of: implementing the solid state shear pulverization through side-by-side, intermeshing, co-rotating screws.
39. The method of claim 1, including the step of: physically reducing the material to powder particles having a size of less than about 500 microns.
40. The method of claim 39, including the step of: maintaining the modified material in an inert atmosphere after discharge.
41. The method of claim 26, including the further step of: processing the discharged material by a process selected from the group consisting of extrusion, molding and coating.
42. The method of claim 41 wherein the further step is selected from the group consisting of rotational molding, blow molding, spray coating, powder coating and thermal spray coating.
43. The method of claim 27, including the step of: physically modifying a multi-colored polymer blend of material to uniform color particles.
44. The method of claim 26, including the step of: morphologically modifying the material to sheared particles.

45. A method of forming modified powders, comprising the step of: (a) providing a mixture of polymeric flake or pellets or mixtures thereof: (b) modifying the flakes into powder by the application of mechanical energy through solid state shear pulverization in the presence of cooling sufficient to maintain the material in the solid state during pulverization to effect a chemical change;
and (c) discharging the resulting powder.

46. The method of claim 45, including the step of: providing as the material to be modified a material selected from the group consisting of virgin polymeric materials, post-consumer polymeric waste materials, amorphous polymeric scrap materials, crystalline polymeric scrap materials, blended polymeric materials, thermodynamically incompatible polymeric blends, multi-colored polymeric blends, industrial polymeric waste materials, and mixtures thereof.
47. The method of claim 46, including the step of: providing as the mixture materials selected from the group consisting of HDPE, LDPE, LLDPE, PP, PS, PET, PVC, PC, ABS/PC, and PPO.
48. The method of claim 45, including the step of: providing as the mixture materials selected from the group consisting of thermoplastics, polymer alloys, thermosets, polymer blends and elastomers.
49. The method of claim 45, including the step of: providing flake materials having a size of from about 0.10 to about 0.30 inches in width and from about 0.02 to about 0.06 inches in thickness.
50. The method of claim 49, including the step of: forming the flake materials by comminution.
51. The method of claim 50, including the step of: implementing the comminution by one of grinding, chopping, and shredding.
52. The method of claim 45, including the step of: forming powder having a size of less than about 500 microns.
53. The method of claim 45, including the step of: creating the mixture from thermodynamically incompatible polymers.
54. The method of claim 45, including the step of: forming powder having a uniform color.
55. The method of claim 45, including the step of: maintaining the powder in an inert atmosphere.

56. The method of claim 45, including the step of: processing the powder by a process selected from the group consisting of molding, blow molding, extrusion, spray coating, powder coating, and thermal spray coating.
57. The method of claim 45, including the step of: maintaining the mixture at a temperature less than the melting temperature of the components.

58. A method of blending materials, comprising the steps of: (a) providing a mixture consisting essentially of different polymeric materials; (b) blending the mixture through the application of mechanical energy through solid state shear pulverization in the presence of cooling sufficient to maintain the materials in the solid state during pulverization and thereby chemically altering, the pulverized material;
and (c) discharging the resulting blended material.

59. The method of claim 58, including the steps of: providing as the mixture materials selected from the group consisting of industrial polymeric scrap, virgin polymeric materials, post-consumer polymeric waste materials, amorphous polymeric scrap materials, crystalline scrap polymeric materials, blended polymeric materials, thermodynamically incompatible polymeric blends, and multi-colored polymeric blends.
60. The method of claim 59, including the step of: providing as the mixture materials selected from the group consisting of HDPE, LDPE, LLDPE, PP, PS, PET, PVC, PC, ABS/PC, and PPO.
61. The method of claim 58, including the step of: providing as the mixture materials selected from the group consisting of thermoplastics, polymer alloys, thermosets, and elastomers.
62. The method of claim 59, including the steps of: (a) providing as the mixture a multi-colored polymer blend;
and (b) discharging uniformly colored particles.
63. The method of claim 62, including the step of: discharging as the particles powder having a size of less than about 500 microns.

64. The method of claim 58, including the step of: providing as the mixture flake materials having a size of from about 0.10 to about 0.30 inches in width and from about 0.02 to about 0.06 inches in thickness.
65. The method of claim 58, including the step of: maintaining the blend under an inert atmosphere.

66. The method of claim 58, including the step of: processing the blend by a process selected from the group consisting of conventional rotational molding, blow molding, extrusion, spray coating, powder coating, and thermal spray coating.
67. The method of claim 66, including the step of: processing the blend without pelletization.
68. The method of claim 59, including the step of: implementing the solid state shear pulverization through at least two intermeshing, co-rotating screws.
69. The method of claim 58, including the step of: morphologically modifying the mixture to sheared particles.
70. The method of claim 1, including the step of: morphologically modifying the mixture of sheared particles.
71. The product of the process of claim 26.
72. The product of the process of claim 1.
73. The product of the process of claim 58.
74. The process of claim 1, 6 or 7 wherein the polymer material comprises a supply of two or more thermodynamically incompatible polymers.
